data.title: Lab Members — Galagan Lab
data.meta_description: We are an interdisciplinary lab at the interface of genomics, molecular biology, computational biology, electrical engineering, and technology development.  We develop computational and high-throughput experimental methods to study the systems biology of microbial organisms and translate the resulti
data.text:
James Galagan, PhD

Principal Investigator, CV

Professor, Biomedical Engineering, Bioinformatics Program

Director, Precision Diagnostics Center

jgalag@bu.edu

Dr. Galagan received his B.S. in Computer and Electrical Engineering from UC Davis, and his PhD in Computational Neuroscience from MIT. In 1998 he joined the Whitehead Institute Center for Genome Research which then became the Broad Institute, where he rose to the position of Associate Director for Microbial Genome Analysis. In 2009, he joined Boston University as an Associate Professor in Biomedical Engineering and Microbiology. He has served as the Associate Director for Systems Biology at the National Emerging Infectious Diseases Laboratory, the Director of the BU Illumina Sequencing Core Facility. He currently serves as the Associate Director for the Precision Diagnostics Center. He enjoys travel, reading, movies and various sporting activities.

Selected Awards

Distinguished Faculty Fellow, College of Engineering

Institute Fellow, Institute for Health System Innovation & Policy

Faculty Startup Award, Massachusetts Life Sciences

Deans Catalyst Award

Víctor Tierrafría, PhD

Víctor has skills in microbiology, biocuration, and genome scale data analyses. He is interested in understanding the ways microbes perceive environmental signals and finely adjust their regulatory mechanisms to adapt to ever changing conditions. He hopes to extrapolate this knowledge to biotech to develop new or improve existing processes.

He joins the group to help performing genome scale experiments and interpreting new results since the physiological point of view, while getting stronger experience in massive data analyses.

He loves food and music, and also to know new places, especially if they involve food.

Postdoctoral Research Fellow (Joined Summer 2021)

PhD Biochemical Sciences (Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México 2019)

MSc Biochemical Sciences (Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México 2011)

BSc Biotechnological Engineering (Instituto Politécnico Nacional 2005)

Zhehao Zhang, PhD

I am interested in electrochemical phenomena (energy transduction at the electrode-solution interface) and applying electrochemical engineering to biosciences. Here at Galagan lab, I am responsible for building next-generation biosensors using proteins (enzymes and transcription factors) harvested from microbes and increasing the sensitivity of sensor for healthcare applications.

In my spare time, I enjoy playing video games, bouldering and playing basketball.

Postdoctoral Research Fellow (Joined Fall 2022)

PhD Biomedical Engineering (University of Illinois Chicago 2022)

M.S. Biomedical Engineering (Case Western Reserve University 2017)

B.S. Bioscience (Huazhong University of Science and Technology 2013)

Roman Addokhi

Roman is fascinated by the intricacy of biology and wants to create a connection between biology and electronics. He aims to use electronics to read from, and write to, biology. Currently, he’s developing an integrated platform for wearable biosensors to perform continuous measurements on the body to help transform healthcare from a reactive, cure-driven, approach, into a proactive and preventative one.

To destress, Roman goes on long hikes, appreciates creative expression through contemporary art, or creates art using unconventional mediums.

PhD Biomedical Engineering Candidate (Joined Fall 2019)

M.S. Biomedical Engineering (Boston University 2019)

B.S. Biomedical Technology (King Saud University 2014)

Hao Zang

Hao’s interests in biosensors, microfluidics and nano/microfabrication of wearable devices have brought him to Galagan Lab. In the lab, he is devoted to developing novel electrodes and a real time platform to collect fluid from human body. He is extending his knowledge to different areas such as electrochemistry, electronics and microbiology.

Besides, Hao enjoys cooking, travelling and sports such as badminton.

Ph.D. Biomedical Engineering (Joined Fall 2021)

M.S. Materials Science and Engineering (Northwestern University, 2021)

B.S. Materials and Nanoscience (Soochow University & University of Waterloo, 2019)

Chris Krenz

Chris is interested in the intersection of computer science, machine learning, and computational biology, which has brought him to the Galagan Lab. He hopes to contribute to the development of new tools for research in microbiology, genomics, and biomedicine.

He also enjoys baking, video/board games, and 3D modeling/printing.

M.S. Electrical and Computer Engineering (Joined Spring 2024)

B.A. Sociology (University of Michigan 2011)

Patrick Lally, PhD

Pat’s interests in computational biology and integration of large high-throughput genomics datasets brought him to the Galagan Lab for his Ph.D. His work covered computational efforts to build upon and manage the lab’s Next-Gen Sequencing analysis infrastructure, as well as experimental work to systematically map direct regulatory targets of E. coli Transcription Factors using binding (ChIP-Seq) and expression (RNA-Seq) assays. His work also led to the development and validation of a predictive biophysical neural network trained on his ChIP-Seq data that can predict TF-DNA binding affinity and ChIP-Seq coverage, and design novel binding sequences with specified affinities, including sequences stronger than those naturally present in E. coli. He now leads the Precision Diagnostics Center’s aim to offer NGS analysis pipelines as a service.

Outside of the lab, Pat is an avid scuba diver and has recently gotten into pickleball.

Ph.D. Biomedical Engineering (Boston University, 2024)

M.S. Biomedical Engineering (Boston University, 2021)

B.S. Biomedical Engineering (University of Miami, FL, 2017)
